title: Alain Calmat
text:
Alain Calmat (born 31 August 1940) is a French former competitive <a href="Figure%20skating">figure skater</a>, <a href="surgeon">surgeon</a>, and <a href="politician">politician</a>. He is the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201964%20Winter%20Olympics">1964 Olympic silver medalist</a>, the <a href="1965%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">1965 World champion</a>, the 1962–1964 <a href="European%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">European champion</a>, and the 1958 & 1962–1965 <a href="French%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">French national champion</a>.
Career.
Calmat attended the <a href="Cours%20Hattemer">Cours Hattemer</a>, a private school. He started skating at the age of nine. He won the silver medal at the <a href="French%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">French Figure Skating Championships</a> in 1954 and would go on to win twelve medals at nationals before retiring: seven silver and five gold. He placed 9th at the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201956%20Winter%20Olympics">1956 Winter Olympics</a> and won the bronze medal at the <a href="1958%20European%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">1958 European Championships</a>. At the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201960%20Winter%20Olympics">1960 Winter Olympics</a>, he moved up to sixth place and won the bronze medal at the <a href="1960%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">1960 World Championships</a>.
The following year, Calmat won the silver medal at the <a href="1961%20European%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">1961 European Championships</a>. He became European champion for three consecutive years from 1962 to 1964. During that period, Calmat was awarded one bronze and two silver medals at Worlds.
At the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201964%20Winter%20Olympics">1964 Winter Olympics</a>, Calmat won the silver medal and went on to win his second consecutive silver medal at <a href="1964%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">Worlds</a>. He stayed in one more season and retired as the <a href="1965%20World%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">1965 World champion</a>.
Calmat carried the torch and lit the Olympic flame at the <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201968%20Winter%20Olympics">1968 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="Grenoble">Grenoble</a>, France.
After skating.
Calmat later studied <a href="medicine">medicine</a>, and became a <a href="surgeon">surgeon</a>.
A <a href="Socialist%20Party%20%28France%29">socialist</a>, he started in a political career. He was <a href="Minister%20of%20Youth%20Affairs%20and%20Sports%20%28France%29">minister of Youth Affairs and Sports</a> between 1984 and 1986 when <a href="Laurent%20Fabius">Laurent Fabius</a> was prime minister. He was elected deputy of the <a href="D%C3%A9partement%20in%20France">département</a> of <a href="Cher%20%28d%C3%A9partement%29">Cher</a> from 1986 until 1993. In 1995, he became the <a href="mayor">mayor</a> of <a href="Livry-Gargan">Livry-Gargan</a>. In 1997 he became a deputy in the <a href="French%20National%20Assembly">French National Assembly</a>.
Calmat was inducted into the <a href="International%20Jewish%20Sports%20Hall%20of%20Fame">International Jewish Sports Hall of Fame</a> in 1987.
